data.title: The Stories Behind 5 Horror Movie Masks
data.meta_description: Michael Myers’s mask from the “Halloween” movies was based on a death mask originally made for Captain Kirk on “Star Trek.”
data.text:
Even before the coronavirus made masks a daily reality, they occupied a mighty space in our cultural imagination as a mainstay of horror movies.

Let’s unmask some classics of the genre →

The Stories Behind 5 Horror Movie Masks

Michael Myers’s mask from the “Halloween” movies was based on a death mask originally made for Captain Kirk on “Star Trek.” To create the vacant look, the designer Tommy Lee Wallace colored the hair and face, and cut larger eye holes.

The Stories Behind 5 Horror Movie Masks

Wes Craven, the director of “Scream,” wasn’t initially sure what the killer’s mask would look like. But a producer found Fun World’s Ghostface mask in a house that Alfred Hitchcock once filmed in — and Craven immediately loved it.

The Stories Behind 5 Horror Movie Masks

In “You’re Next,” a family is attacked by three men wearing a lamb mask, a fox mask and a tiger mask. The screenwriter, Simon Barrett, said in an interview with IGN, “If the movie has a theme, it’s what people are hiding on the inside.”

The Stories Behind 5 Horror Movie Masks

The grotesque mask from the 2012 horror movie “Smiley” (left) recalls the smiley emoticon. It’s well-matched to the movie’s theme, about a killer who can be summoned via the internet to murder people.
